Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Mechanisms of host preference in the ectomycorrhizal symbiosis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Although mutually beneficial interactions are important in many natural systems, it remains unclear why some involve highly specialized partners, while others do not. This project investigates how different degrees of specificity have evolved and function in a particular type of symbiosis - a mutualistic relationship between a fungus and many temperate forest plants. This research will combine a fungus with multiple, distantly related host plants to investigate how the fungus alters its symbiotic behavior when interacting with different species of plants. This experiment will generate insight into symbiotic plant-microbe communication in this important mutualism, and will allow for comparison to similar systems in pathogens. Outreach to science enrichment programs for urban youth in San Francisco will also occur.

This study will use RNA sequencing to determine the genetic basis of generalist host preference in the ectomycorrhizal fungus Thelephora terrestris. Six plant species from four families will be established in microcosms and inoculated with spores from Thelephora terrestris. At symbiotic maturity, microcosms will be labeled with carbon-13 and nitrogen-15 and plant, fungal, and symbiotic tissues will be harvested for isotope analysis and RNA sequencing. Transcriptional data will be combined with stable isotope enrichment measurements of plant and fungal resource allocation and compared across different plant-fungus combinations. Measuring gene expression in symbiotic tissues while simultaneously tracking resource allocation will reveal which genes are associated with improved symbiotic performance, providing a powerful link between gene transcription, physiological function, and the stability of mutualistic interactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to investigate the genetic basis of host range and resource exchange in ectomycorrhizal symbiosis, a common plant-fungal mutualism that is crucial to the nutrition of many temperate forest plants. This symbiosis is based around an exchange of resources: Plants send carbon to the fungi on their roots in exchange for nitrogen and other resources that the fungi have extracted from the soil. Most ectomycorrhizal fungi can trade these resources with many species of host plant, often simultaneously, but it remains unknown how these fungi maintain relationships with such diverse partners. This project combined an ectomycorrhizal fungus with six distantly related host plants to investigate how the fungus altered its symbiotic behavior when interacting with different plants. We had two major aims: First, to understand what genetic tools might be required for a fungus to associate with many hosts, and second, to investigate whether the fungus would trade resources differently with different host plant species. These insights will contribute to our understanding of how host range may evolve and change in ectomycorrhizal fungi, and will improve our understanding of just how dynamic carbon and nutrient exchange between plants and fungi may be in temperate and boreal forests.

To address our two aims, we used RNA sequencing and stable isotope enrichment to investigate symbiosis between one ectomycorrhizal fungus with broad host range, Thelephora terrestris, and six host plants in four families (Pinaceae, Salicaceae, Fagaceae, and Ericaceae). We used RNA sequencing to compare the genes that the fungus was using in each host root to a non-symbiotic reference (gene expression in soil), and to compare the genes it used in each host plant to those it used in the others. We also used stable isotope enrichment to investigate how much carbon each host plant gave to the fungus, and how much nitrogen the fungus gave back to each host in return. We tracked the extent to which the fungus benefitted the growth of each plant, and how much of the root system the fungus occupied on average for each host species.

We found that the fungus generally provided every host plant the same relative amount of nitrogen for the carbon it received, but that the host plants differed dramatically in the overall quantity of resources traded with this fungus. Pacific madrone, in particular, traded much more carbon with T. terrestris than the other plants, and received more nitrogen in return. This host also received the greatest benefit from symbiosis with T. terrestris. Despite the success of the symbiosis, very little of the madrone root system was typically colonized by T. terrestris. The best-colonized plant, Bishop pine, didn't appear to benefit much from the association. Contrary to previous assumptions, these results show that more colonized roots do not necessarily mean that a plant is trading more with a fungus, or benefitting more from the association.

The RNA sequencing revealed a great deal of variation in fungal gene expression both within and between host environments. When fungal gene expression changed consistently across host plants, the genes involved tended to have their expression reduced: their functions included cell adhesion, signaling, and carbon metabolism. In the most host-beneficial symbiosis, the fungus expressed some genes at higher levels than in the other symbioses, including genes related to transport and carbon metabolism, consistent with the active resource trade we observed in this symbiosis.

Overall, although T. terrestris could engage in symbiosis with many host plants, it preferred some hosts over others, trading resources and benefitting plant growth to different extents depending on host plant identity. This variation in symbiotic behavior was paralleled by great variation in gene expression across host environments. If this pattern is consistent among other fungal generalists, it suggests that broad host association may be genetically costly over evolutionary time, perhaps helping to explain why some fungi specialize. It further suggests that we must not only understand how diverse a forest is, but specifically which fungi are interacting with which plants, and how much trade those interactions represent, to understand resource cycling in forested systems. This project revealed the dynamism and complexity of ectomycorrhizal mutualism, even for just one fungus, and identified genes that may have important functions in symbiosis.

DDIG funding also supported Co-PI Bogar's development as a mentor and public communicator. She trained eleven undergraduate and two high school researchers through the course of this research, helping them acquire skills ranging from microscopy to datalogger programming. She also presented the results at scientific conferences and public lectures during the award period. We are currently preparing manuscripts for publication in scientific journals.
